tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
God beginning to act is spoke of as if he stands up. AT: "Let God begin to act" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "let God chase away his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: As smoke is driven away, so drive them away
tn.text: God's enemies are spoken of as if they are smoke that is easily blown away by the wind. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Drive them away as the wind blows away smoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: as wax melts before the fire
tn.text: God's enemies are spoken of as if they are wax that is easily melted by a fire. AT: "cause them to disappear as wax melts before a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the wicked people in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This refers to the righteous people in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
These means the same thing and emphasizes the amount of joy they feel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This refers to God. AT: "to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the one who rides through the plains
tn.text: God's presence among people is spoken of as if he rides on the earth in a horse or chariot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God is spoken of as a compassionate God who acts like a father to orphans. AT: "One who acts like a father to children who have no parents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God is spoken of as a merciful God who protects widows. AT: "a protector of widows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: God puts the lonely into families
tn.text: God is spoken of as if he places lonely people into families. "God provides families for those who have no one to live with" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he brings out the prisoners with singing
tn.text: God is spoken of as the one who leads prisoners out of their confinement. AT: "God frees prisoners and makes them sing with happiness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This refers to the rebellious people. The abstract word "rebellious" can be stated as an action. AT: "those who rebel against him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
God's punishment of the rebellious is spoken of as if he forces them to live in a hot desert land. AT: "a very hot and dry land" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David begins to tell the story of God leading the Israelites through the desert to Mt. Sinai.

tn.ref: when you went out ... when you marched through
tn.text: These two phrases refer to the same event. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you went out before your people
tn.text: " you led your people"

tn.ref: when you marched through the wilderness
tn.text: God is spoken of as if he was a soldier marching ahead of the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the heavens also dropped rain ... God's presence
tn.text: "God caused it to rain"
This idiom here refers to God's appearance before the Israelites. AT: "when God appeared to the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you strengthened your inheritance when it was weary
tn.text: The land of Israel is spoken of as if it was a person who could be weary, or could gain strength. AT: "you caused the land to produce good crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The land that God gave to the Israelites is spoken of as if it was an inheritance that a father passed on to his children. AT: "the land that you gave to us Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to poor people in general. AT: "poor people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
David continues the story of the journey of the Israelites through the desert. In this part of the story, the Israelites are victorious in war over their enemies.

The large number of people told the Lord's message to others. They are spoken of as if there were a large army. Since this phrase is feminine, some versions translate it as, "the women who announced them ... army." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Kings of armies ... why did you do this?
tn.text: The information in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:068:011|68:12-13]] has been rearranged so its meaning can be more easily understood. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_versebridge]])

tn.ref: Kings of armies flee, they flee
tn.text: The kings represent their entire armies. It is understood that they flee because they are defeated by Israel's army. AT: "Kings and their armies flee from us because they are defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
things that are taken from the defeated army and brought to the victorious army's home.
This means that some of the plunder is very valuable because it is covered with precious metals.

tn.ref: When some of you people stayed among the sheepfolds, why did you do this?
tn.text: This question is used to rebuke the people who did not participate in the battle. AT: "Those who stayed among the sheepfolds should not have stayed; they should have gone to the battle." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: scattered kings there ... snowed on Mount Zalmon
tn.text: There were so many dead kings and soldiers on the mountain that they are spoken of as if they were snow covering the mountain. AT: "defeated so many enemy kings and soldiers there that they were like snowflakes covering Mount Zalmon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here "kings" refers to their armies as well. AT: "scattered the enemy kings and their armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a mountain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: A mighty mountain is the ... a high mountain is the
tn.text: These two phrase have similar meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. AT: "a mighty and high mountain is the hill country of Bashan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Why do you look in envy ... for the place he will live?
tn.text: This question can be written as a statement. AT: "The high hill country of Bashan should not look in envy at the mountain which God desires for the place he will live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is probably not meant to be an exact number, but to indicate a large number. AT: "many thousands" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
To "ascend" is to to move up, to go toward the sky.
"carries our heavy loads every day." The Lord's care for his people is spoken of as if he was physically carrying their troubles as a burden. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the God who is our salvation ... Our God is a God who saves
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. Here "is our salvation" can be translated with the verb "save." AT: "the God who saves us ... Our God is a God who saves us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: will strike through the heads of his enemies
tn.text: God is spoken of as a warrior who will kill his enemies by striking them in their heads in order to kill them. AT: "will kill his enemies by striking them in the head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It seems to have been the custom for soldiers not to cut their hair during the time of war. AT: "the long-haired skulls" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Offending God is spoken of as walking among the offenses. AT: "habitually offend him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "them" refers to God's enemies.
This is an idiom that refers to the most remote parts of the earth where people might try to escape from God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The total destruction of Israel's enemies is spoken of as if the Israelites had crushed them under their feet. AT: "totally defeat your enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The violence of from the destruction of the enemies is spoke of in very graphic form, as if the Israelites would be standing in the blood of their dead enemies. AT: "stepping in their blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the tongues of your dogs may have their share
tn.text: The bloodshed from the battle against Israel's enemies is spoken of as if it is so extensive that the dogs will lap up the flowing blood with their tongues. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
A procession is a group of people walking together in an orderly manner as part of a ceremony.
people who play musical instruments

tn.ref: Bless God in the assembly; praise Yahweh, you true descendants of Israel
tn.text: It may be helpful to change the order of these phrases. AT: "You who are the true descendants of Israel, praise Yahweh and bless God in the assembly"
"their group." The word "their" refers to the leaders of Judah.

tn.ref: Your God, Israel, has decreed your strength
tn.text: Some versions understand the Hebrew text differently: "Summon (or use) your strength, God"
"People of Israel, your God has decreed"
The word "us" refers to the people David is speaking to and to himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: Reveal your power to us from your temple at Jerusalem
tn.text: "When you are present in the temple at Jerusalem, show us your power"
The abstract noun "power" can be stated as an action. AT: "Show us that you are strong" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the wild beasts in the reeds
tn.text: Many scholars believe these wild beasts are a metaphor that refers to the people of Egypt. This can be made explicit. AT: "the people of Egypt who are like wild beasts in the reeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the peoples, that multitude of bulls and calves
tn.text: The peoples of other nations are spoken of as if they were a large group of cattle. AT: "the powerful nations, who are like herds of bulls" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
to disperse or to cause something to spread quickly in different direction

tn.ref: Princes will come out of Egypt
tn.text: It is implied that these princes come from Egypt in order to offer gifts to God in Jerusalem. AT: "Then the leaders of Egypt will bring gifts to you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the people of Ethiopia. AT: "The Ethiopians" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: reach out with her hands to God
tn.text: This is a symbolic action that represents worship to God. AT: "lift up her hands to praise God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Here "kingdoms" refers to the citizens of the kingdoms. AT: "you people who are citizens of kingdoms all over the world" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: To him who rides on the heaven of heavens
tn.text: The word "Sing" is implied as the beginning of this verse. Here God is described as if he rides in a chariot in the sky. AT: "Sing to God who rides across the sky in his chariot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he lifts up his voice with power
tn.text: This idiom means he speaks powerfully. AT: "he shouts powerfully" or "he speaks loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Ascribe" means to give credit to someone. AT: "Strength belongs to God"

tn.ref: his strength is in the skies
tn.text: The abstract noun "strength" can be stated as an action. AT: "in the skies he also shows that he is powerful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: God, you are fearsome in your holy place
tn.text: Here the author speaks directly to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
These two words mean basically these same thing. They emphasize how much strength God provides to his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
